div.p: This paper studies the stability and stabilization problems for time-delay nonlinear systems through Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model approach. The time delays are assumed to be bounded but perhaps non-smooth. Delay-dependent conditions are presented in terms of LMIs. Illustrative examples are given to show the effectiveness and merits of the present results.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Among various schemes developed for the analysis and synthesis of complex nonlinear systems, fuzzy logic control is an attractive and effective rule-based one. It has emerged as a paradigm of intelligent control capable of dealing with complex and ill-defined systems for which the application of conventional control techniques is not straightforward or feasible. In many of the model-based fuzzy control approaches, the well-known Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model [14] is a popular and convenient tool in functional approximations. Such a model consists of a family of local linear models smoothly connected through nonlinear fuzzy membership functions. During the last decade, the stability and stabilization problem for systems in T-S fuzzy model has been studied extensively and numerous methods have been proposed [8,10,12,[15][16][17][18][19].

Recently, in view of possible time-delays in practical systems, analysis and control of T-S fuzzy systems with timedelay have been also addressed [1,2,21]. In [1], the time-delay is assumed to be smooth (i.e., the derivative of time-delay is bounded) and LMI conditions are given for the analysis and synthesis of time-delay fuzzy systems. Practically, one may concern that it is very hard to know whether or not the derivative of time-delay does exist. In view of this, the non-smooth delay case (i.e., inexistence of the derivative of time-delay) is considered in [2,21] and different LMIbased strategies are proposed. In [21], another algebraic inequality method is also provided for the stability analysis and fuzzy control design. The problem of H ∞ control for time-delay fuzzy systems is studied in [9]. All the above work is concerned with delay-independent methods.

In general, delay-dependent criteria are considered less conservative than delay-independent ones in studying dynamical systems with time-delays, particularly when the delay is small. Currently, various delay-dependent conditions have been reported for the analysis and control of time-delay systems (see [3][4][5]11,13,20] and the references therein). However, so far there has been a little work done for control design of time-delay fuzzy systems using delay-dependent techniques. Quite recently, a delay-dependent guaranteed cost control design approach has been proposed for T-S fuzzy systems with time delays [6]. It is noted that the time-delay considered in [6] is assumed to be smooth. Thus, the analysis and control method therein could be obtained by adopting appropriate Lyaponuv-Krasovskii functionals analogous to those of [1] and using a delay-dependent technique similar to those of [5,11,13].

Motivated by the above observations, in this paper we will investigate T-S fuzzy systems with non-smooth timevarying delays and present delay-dependent methods for the stability analysis and fuzzy control design. The considered type of time-delay is the same as in [2,21]. By using the Razumikhin Theorem (see [7]), we will establish sufficient delay-dependent conditions in terms of LMIs. The present results will be shown less conservative than the delayindependent ones in [2,21] when time-delay is small. We point out that the delay-dependent method in [6] does not help as the Lyaponuv-Krasovskii functionals therein are not applicable to non-smooth delay cases. The effectiveness of our results will be shown by several examples for which the existing delay-independent results fail to draw a conclusion.

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 gives the problem formulation and preliminaries. Section 3 presents several delay-dependent stability results for the considered time-delay fuzzy systems. Comparisons with delay-independent results are also done in this section. Section 4 establishes the delay-dependent stabilization results in terms of LMIs. Section 5 gives three examples to illustrate the effectiveness and merits of our results. This paper is concluded in Section 6.

The notations used in this paper are quite standard: R denotes the field of real numbers while R + the set of nonnegative real numbers; R n denotes the n-dimensional real Euclidean space; I is the identity matrix of appropriate dimensions; the superscripts 'T' and '-1' stand for the matrix transpose and inverse, respectively; W > 0 (W < 0) means that W is symmetric and positive (negative) definite; min (•) and max (•) denote, respectively, the smallest and the largest eigenvalue of a matrix; • denotes the spectral norm.

div.head: Comparisons with delay-independent results
div.p: It has been stated earlier that delay-dependent criteria are usually considered less conservative than delay-independent ones in studying time-delay systems, particularly when the delay is small. In this subsection, we will compare our results with existing delay-independent results in the related work [2,21]. We will show that, when the delay is small, our results are less conservative than those in [2,21]. Please note that for large time-delay case, the comparison cannot be done as there is no implication relation between our results and those of [2,21].

For briefness in comparison, the conditions in Theorem 3.1, Proposition 3.1 and Theorem 3.2 are called Condition 1, Condition 1 and Condition 2, respectively. In order not to cause any misunderstanding, we would like to point out here that there are two mistypings appeared in Corollary 1 and Theorem 3 of [21], i.e., the (2, 2) entries should read "-(1/k s )P " and "-(1/ s )P ", respectively, rather than "-k s P " and "s P ". The above comparisons clearly show the implication relations between our delay-dependent results and existing delay-independent results. We emphasize that although choosing some common matrices in the conditions of Theorems 3.1 and 3.2 may bring conservativeness, the resulting criteria are still less conservative than the existing delayindependent methods in case of small delays. div.head: Design of fuzzy controllers
div.p: This section focuses on the delay-dependent design of state feedback stabilizing fuzzy controllers for the fuzzy system (2). div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, we have studied the stability and stabilization problems for T-S fuzzy systems with bounded timevarying delays in the state and control input. The time delays are not confined to smooth delays. The main contribution lies in that delay-dependent conditions are given in terms of LMIs. These results are very useful complements for delay-independent ones in the literature of time-delay fuzzy systems. Comparisons are shown that the present delaydependent methods are less conservative than the existing delay-independent methods for small delays. The advantages

The disadvantage of the results is that a large number of LMIs have to be computed if the number of IF-THEN rules, r, is big. Quantitative details have been shown that the large number could be reduced if choosing common matrices in solving LMIs.
